insights.title: Dramatic increase in unit price
insights.observation: Average price per unit rose from $2,822 (historical) to $472,500 in the current period, a 16,600% increase.
insights.recommendation: Negotiate pricing with the existing supplier, explore alternative vendors for boiler water chemicals, and conduct a cost‑benefit analysis to justify the high unit cost.

insights.title: Order volume collapsed
insights.observation: Quantity purchased dropped from 692 units historically to just 2 units this period, a 99.7% decline.
insights.recommendation: Review demand forecasting and internal consumption patterns to determine if the drop reflects true demand or a procurement bottleneck, and adjust ordering processes accordingly.

insights.title: Spend positioned between median and 75th percentile
insights.observation: Current period spend of $945,000 is 78% higher than the industry median ($531,781) yet 90% lower than the 75th percentile ($9,409,248).
insights.recommendation: Benchmark against peers in the 75th percentile to identify growth opportunities and consider scaling procurement volumes to achieve better economies of scale.

insights.title: Extremely low purchase volume
insights.observation: Only 2 units were purchased this period, which is 98% below the industry 25th‑percentile volume of 161 units and far under the median of 510 units.
insights.recommendation: Consolidate orders, explore bulk purchasing options, or assess whether the procurement function is under‑utilized and can be expanded to capture more volume.

insights.title: Single‑supplier reliance exceeds typical benchmarks
insights.observation: All $945,000 of spend is sourced from a single supplier (100% concentration). Industry median suppliers = 1, but the 75th percentile is 3.25 and the 90th percentile is 8, indicating higher concentration risk.
insights.recommendation: Diversify the supplier base by qualifying additional vendors for boiler water chemicals and other high‑cost items to mitigate supply‑chain risk.

insights.title: Shift to water‑treatment category
insights.observation: Historically the top spend category was "Building construction machinery and accessories" ($1,008,000). In the current period the top category is "Water treatment and supply equipment" ($945,000), indicating a strategic shift in procurement focus.
insights.recommendation: Analyze the drivers behind the category change, ensure procurement policies align with the new focus, and evaluate alternative suppliers for water‑treatment chemicals to optimize cost and risk.
